docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have found that people who eat fish regularly from the Hudson River have twice as much mercury in their blood as others, according to a study.

headline.main: Despite Warnings, Many Persist in Eating Fish From the Hudson

docs.lead_paragraph: The Defense Department discharged 726 service members last year for being gay, up about 10 percent from 2004, figures released by a gay rights group show.

headline.main: Military’s Discharges for Being Gay Rose in ’05

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who feel anxious during pregnancy should not worry that their feelings will affect their babies, a new report suggests.

headline.main: Maternity: Anxious Mothers and Their Calmer Babies
headline.print_headline: Anxious Mothers and Their Calmer Babies

docs.snippet: Women who feel anxious during pregnancy should not worry that their feelings will affect their babies, a new report suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who feel anxious during pregnancy should not worry that their feelings will affect their babies, a new report suggests. The report, a review of 50 studies, found no significant associations between feeling anxious and negative outcomes in pregnancy or birth. The findings are online now and will be printed in a future issue of The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

headline.main: Anxious Mothers and Their Calmer Babies

docs.abstract: Heather L Littleton, Sam Houston State University assistant psychology professor, leads study on possible impact of anxiety on mothers-to-be; research, which is published in American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, finds no evidence of negative pregnancy outcomes associated with anxiety; drawing (M)
